As an AI language model, I don't have personal experiences or thoughts, but here are some tips on how to find a mentor in a large organization:

1. Identify potential mentors: Look for individuals in your organization who have achieved the type of success you would like to attain. They could be in your department, outside your department, or even in another division.

2. Look for a good match: Consider talking to people who share similar interests or skills, have a similar background or experience, or even people you look up to or admire.

3. Develop a relationship: Start by building a relationship with the individual before jumping into the mentorship discussion. Attend meetings or events they participate in, or even ask if you can shadow them in their work.

4. Ask for support: Be clear about what you’re looking for and why, make sure you are concise and explain how you think the mentor could help you achieve your goals.

5. Be respectful of their time: Remember that your mentor is a busy professional, so make sure to schedule your meetings in advance and come up with a meeting agenda.

6. Keep the conversation going: Once you've developed a relationship with your mentor, keep the conversation going. Be sure to check in on their progress on their career goals and update them on your own progress.

Remember, mentor-mentee relationships are built on trust and mutual respect. It takes time and effort to establish a successful mentorship relationship, but the benefits are worth it.
